title: Lumbers boss says reaction to Brexit vote has led to huge opportunities for retailers | Leicester Mercury
text:
Lumbers boss says reaction to Brexit vote has led to huge opportunities for retailers By Leicester Mercury | Posted: August 23, 2016 0 COMMENTS SHARES Dominic Gomersall, MD of Lumbers, with his son Freddie Lumbers boss says reaction to Brexit vote has led to huge opportunities for... X 
Copy link to paste in your message / Comments (0) 
Dominic Gomersall, the managing director of Lumbers jewellers in Leicester, on why Britain's decision to leave the EU could be good for business 
Brexit continues to divide discussions and bring many differing opinions to the fore. The media and public hysteria has been unabated although many of the principles of the pre-vote campaigning have already, seemingly, proved impotent. 
The Bank of England's complete change of tact from forecasting an interest rate increase prior to the vote and actually implementing a decrease shouldn't come as a shock to many who watched both campaigns sway from policy to policy. 
Of course, the initial exchange rate fluctuations have provided a challenge to many and are probably the highest profile consequence of the uncertainty created. 
But this has led to huge opportunities for many retailers. 
Fortunately for Lumbers, the drop in the value of the pound against the US dollar on the exchange rate has increased the opportunities to export. 
Read more: Inside the new Lumbers store on the High Street - in pictures 
Over the generations of the business, we have cultivated some extremely wealthy international clients. 
We have seen these clients take advantage of the situation by realising that the UK is currently the least expensive market for quality Swiss brands in the world. 
We have been lucky enough to have exported sales of Breguet, Chopard and Hublot watches and have actually had a record July on this basis, seeing a 40 per cent increase on last year. 
This is also fueled by the emergence of Leicester as an international city. 
The universities bring an abundance of foreign students to the area who frequent the High Street regularly. 
Our new location takes advantage of the King Richard III exhibition and Highcross shopping centre where the majority of visitors go. 
Lumbers has been fortunate as we are shielded from the exchange rate issues on importing. 
Swiss watch brands sell to us in pounds sterling and therefore we haven't been exposed to the rise of the euro's value against the pound. 
The Bank of England's recent drop in interest rates, blamed on Brexit, again is extremely helpful to Lumbers. 
With our large capital expenditure last year moving to our wonderful new home, any interest rate drop is assistive. 
Read more: REACTION: Interest rates cut to record low of 0.25 per cent 
I think it was a huge relief to many retailers with the refreshing honesty of Next blaming the unseasonal weather on their latest sales figures rather than Brexit which the media seemed to prefer. 
I have also witnessed a number of important clients that have discreetly used Brexit as an excuse for any redundancies or bad news known of long before the final result. 
I am sure the reaction to Brexit to date has helped a number of businesses, although I am aware how difficult it must be for many importers.
